Situation1: They notice a few pool chairs are slightly misaligned but still usable.
Expectation2: Provide spiritual guidance and counseling to individuals in need
Situation2: A member of the community has scheduled an appointment to discuss a persistent personal struggle.
Story: I stood at the edge of the pool, clipboard in hand, scanning the deck for anything out of place. The sun glinted off the water, and the usual chatter of swimmers filled the air. My eyes landed on a cluster of pool chairs—slightly misaligned, not dangerous, but not up to standard either. I knew I should fix them, keep everything orderly, as expected of a lifeguard. But my phone buzzed in my pocket, a reminder of the appointment I’d promised to keep. A member of my congregation was waiting in the chapel, needing guidance, someone to listen and offer comfort. I felt the weight of both uniforms pressing on me—the whistle around my neck, the collar at my throat. Should I pause my rounds to offer spiritual counsel, or stay and ensure the pool met every safety and appearance standard? The demands pulled at me, each urgent in its own way, and I stood frozen, caught between the needs of the body and the needs of the soul.
